title: Thomas Calculus Early Transcendentals 13th c2014 solutions ISM
description:
Instructor solutions manual (ISM) for "Thomas' Calculus: Early Transcendentals", 13th Edition (c2014), textbook by George B. Thomas Jr., Maurice D. Weir & Joel R. Hass.
(ISM ISBN-13: 9780321884084 + 9780321879011; cannot be bought)

This ISM comes in 2 convenient parts that satisfy the equation:
full calculus (ch 01-17) = single variable calculus (ch 01-11) + multivariable calculus (ch 10-17)

TEXTBOOK INFO:
full 13th ET : <a href=" http://www.pearsonhighered.com/educator/product/9780321884077.page" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW"> http://www.pearsonhighered.com/educator/product/9780321884077.page</a>
single 13th ET : <a href=" http://www.pearsonhighered.com/educator/product/9780321888549.page" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW"> http://www.pearsonhighered.com/educator/product/9780321888549.page</a>
multi 13th : <a href=" http://www.pearsonhighered.com/educator/product/9780321884053.page" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW"> http://www.pearsonhighered.com/educator/product/9780321884053.page</a>
full 13th regular : <a href=" http://www.pearsonhighered.com/educator/product/9780321878960.page" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW"> http://www.pearsonhighered.com/educator/product/9780321878960.page</a>

TEXTBOOK AVAILABILITY: None that I know of (for free)

ISM FILE INFO (both files): paginated, bookmarked, true PDF; files are foldered (Thomas Calculus Early Transcendentals 13th c2014 solutions ISM)
compressed (zipped): *right-click* the filename (.7z) & choose *Extract* to convert to PDF; discard the .7z file (container) when done with seeding.

COMMENT: This ISM can also be used with the regular version of Thomas calculus (Thomas' Calculus 13th c2014) after simple inspection. Thomas' Calculus 13th and Thomas' Calculus ET 13th both have the same problem set as they both cover the exact same topics, only a little differently as the book titles suggest (problem numbering in each version is different for this reason). In the regular version of calculus, transcendental functions (LOG, EXP, ARC) are covered in a separate chapter *after* the derivative and integration concepts have been introduced. In the early transcendentals (ET) version, transcendental functions are treated along with regular functions as the derivative and integration concepts are being developed. Students in an engineering or physics program need the calculus handling of these special functions concurrently in some other courses of their semester curriculum, so they study them earlier than students in health or administrative sciences.
